title: Early Presidents: Washington and Jefferson

vocab.definition: An example that becomes a standard for others to follow
A group of advisors to the president
A group of people with similar political beliefs
The 1803 purchase of land from France that doubled the nation's size
The policy of not taking sides in conflicts

teachingNotes: Emphasize precedents set by Washington and Jefferson's contributions. Discuss how early decisions shaped American government.

sample.question: What was the Louisiana Purchase?
expectedAny: 1803 purchase from France that doubled nation's size

sample.question: What precedent did Washington set about presidential terms?
expectedAny: not serving more than two terms

sample.question: From which country did we buy Louisiana?
What did Washington's Farewell Address warn about?

truefalse.question: George Washington was the first president. (True or False)
Thomas Jefferson was the second president. (True or False)
The Louisiana Purchase doubled the nation's size. (True or False)
Washington set the precedent of a two-term limit. (True or False)
The cabinet is a group of presidential advisors. (True or False)
Neutrality means taking sides in conflicts. (True or False)
The Louisiana Purchase happened in 1803. (True or False)
Political parties are groups with similar beliefs. (True or False)
We bought Louisiana from Spain. (True or False)
A precedent is an example for others to follow. (True or False)

multiplechoice.question: Who was the first president of the United States?
What did the Louisiana Purchase do?

choices.text: Gave us access to the Pacific

multiplechoice.question: From which country did we buy Louisiana?
When did the Louisiana Purchase occur?
What precedent did Washington set about terms?

choices.text: A group with similar political beliefs

fillintheblank.question: The _____ Purchase doubled the nation's size.
A _____ is an example that becomes standard.
The president's advisors are called the _____.
A group with similar political beliefs is a political _____.
_____ means not taking sides in conflicts.
Washington set the precedent of serving only _____ terms.

shortanswer.question: Why was George Washington important to American government?
expectedAny: He was the first president and set important precedents
Washington established examples for future presidents to follow
As first president he created standards for the office

shortanswer.question: What was the Louisiana Purchase and why was it significant?
expectedAny: The 1803 purchase from France that doubled the nation's size
Buying Louisiana Territory from France doubled America's size
It was land bought from France in 1803 that made the country twice as large

shortanswer.question: What precedents did Washington set?
expectedAny: Two-term limit, cabinet system, and neutrality in foreign affairs
He established the two-term tradition and created the cabinet
Washington set examples like serving only two terms and using advisors

shortanswer.question: How did Thomas Jefferson expand the nation?
expectedAny: Through the Louisiana Purchase of 1803 which doubled the nation's size
He bought Louisiana from France in 1803 doubling the country
Jefferson purchased Louisiana Territory making the nation twice as large

shortanswer.question: What is the cabinet and why is it important?
expectedAny: The cabinet is presidential advisors who help make decisions
A group of advisors that helps the president govern
Presidential advisors who provide expertise and guidance

shortanswer.question: Why did Washington warn against political parties?
expectedAny: He feared they would divide the nation and create conflict
Washington worried parties would harm national unity
He believed parties would cause division instead of unity

shortanswer.question: What does neutrality mean in foreign policy?
expectedAny: Not taking sides in foreign conflicts or wars
Staying neutral and avoiding involvement in other nations' disputes
The policy of not choosing sides in international conflicts

shortanswer.question: How did Washington's precedents affect future presidents?
expectedAny: His examples became standards that future presidents followed
Washington's precedents created traditions other presidents respected
His actions established expectations for how presidents should serve

shortanswer.question: What role did early presidents play in shaping government?
expectedAny: They established precedents and traditions for the new government
Early presidents created the foundation for how government would work
They set standards and examples that shaped American democracy

shortanswer.question: Why was the two-term precedent important?
expectedAny: It limited presidential power and became an important tradition
The two-term limit prevented presidents from having too much power
It established peaceful transfer of power as a tradition
